analysis.raw_analysis:
1) TRANSFORMATION TYPE: Grid size unchanged (10x10). A single color-2 pixel is replaced by a fixed up-right diagonal "stair" of color 2.

2) PATTERN: Consistently expand the lone 2 into the same staircase-shaped connected region of 2s; color-1 shapes and background 0 are left in place.

3) KEY CHANGES:
- Ex1: 2 at (9,1) -> staircase of 2s; 1 at (6,3) remains 1.
- Ex2: 2 at (9,1) -> staircase of 2s; no 1s present.
- Ex3: 2 at (9,0) -> staircase of 2s; 1s at (5,4),(7,1) preserved.
- Ex4: 2 at (9,3) -> staircase of 2s; no 1s changed.

=== INPUT-INPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Differences: the lone color-2 pixel changes column (x) but is always on row 9. Color-1 objects (other colors) vary in number, size and position.
- Same: exactly one color-2 pixel in each input, on the bottom row; other colored objects present and arbitrary.

=== OUTPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Exactly the same: a fixed up-right "stair" shape composed of color 2 (same offsets, size, orientation) appears in every output. Color-1 pixels remain unchanged.

=== INPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Rule: replace the single input color-2 pixel by drawing the fixed color-2 up-right stair anchored at that pixel; preserve all other colors/positions.

- Reference objects: the lone color-2 pixel on row 9 is invariant (only its column moves). It is the anchor that determines where to place the pattern.

- Grid pattern: replace that single pixel with a fixed multi-cell up‑right diagonal "stair" shape of color 2 (same orientation/shape in every example), keeping grid size.

- Objects: the critical object is the single color-2 anchor; other colored objects are secondary and are preserved.

=== GENERAL RULE ===
1) Work on a 10x10 grid: find the single pixel of color 2; in every training input this color-2 pixel is the unique color-2 and lies on the bottom row (row index 9).  
2) Leave every pixel that is not color 2 unchanged (in particular all color-1 objects and background 0 remain exactly as they were).  
3) Replace that lone color-2 pixel by a fixed, multi-cell “staircase” shape composed entirely of color 2. The staircase is always the same shape and orientation: it extends upward and to the right from the original pixel, forming a connected up-right diagonal stair (the original color-2 becomes the bottom-left cell of that stair).  
4) The transformation does not change the grid size or any colors other than adding the color-2 cells of the staircase; no other colored objects are removed or recolored.  
5) The staircase is placed so its relative offsets to the original anchor pixel are constant across examples (i.e., the pattern is translated so the anchor aligns with the original color-2), producing the same arrangement of color-2 cells in every output apart from horizontal translation determined by the input anchor column.  
6) If other colored pixels (e.g. color 1) lie elsewhere in the grid they remain in place and the staircase is drawn on the background positions; the rule as shown in the training set never requires overwriting or recoloring existing non-zero pixels.  
7) In short: detect the unique color-2 on row 9, and replace it by a fixed up-right staircase of color 2 (same shape and orientation each time), translating that staircase horizontally so its bottom-left cell sits at the original color-2; leave all other pixels unchanged.
